comments.author: Kidz24

comments.text:
"Jaws" is kind of like "Duel", only with a great white shark, instead of a 
diesel semi truck. Same kind of concept though. One man against a lurking, 
seemingly emotionless killer, who's intent is unknown, but all too 
apparent.﻿
comments.author: bluestate69

comments.text: Actually Speilberg once joked that Jaws was a sequel to Duel.
comments.author: Franco Carmona

comments.text:
omg..you're like my brother from another mother...I use this line ALL the 
time..love that you posted it!
comments.author: Amily Demler

comments.text:
+Zachary Duke
Well, I am sure your teacher will be impressed with you observations. Its 
always easier to learn, when you're actually interested in the subject 
matter.
I suppose it started with "Moby Dick", and maybe "King Kong", but Speilberg 
really broke ground, and pushed boundaries, of what could be a villain. I 
just recently watched "Dante's Peak" (not that great of a movie), and the 
villain or antagonists was the volcano, and the town's people who refused 
to recognize its potential danger. Sound familiar? ha.
comments.author: bluestate69

comments.text:
That sounds like a really cool course. In my opinion, that sounds a really 
beautiful way to take yourself out of just viewing it for the sole value of 
entertainment, like you watch it, enjoy it, and then it's over (which isn't 
a bad thing by any means), but actually visualizing each frame as a 
painting is just... so cool. Thank you for sharing, this is something I'll 
think about from now on when I analyze movies. 

Thank you! I'm proud of the finished result of it. And it was my idea, we 
had to critically assess (negatively or positively) Spielberg's direction 
of Jaws. It was an incredibly open ended and broad narrative, so I just 
thought it'd be fun to tie in Duel in there, because I really do love how 
similar the two scenes look.
comments.author: Zachary Duke

comments.text:
+Zachary Duke That's cool. Actually, your response reminded me of being in 
film class (took a couple in college). Where you look at each scene as a 
portrait or a painting, and look at how the director frames each scene (the 
"mise en scene"). Good luck on the paper. Was "Duel" and "Jaws" your 
choice, or the teachers?
comments.author: bluestate69

comments.text:
Thank you! And I accidentally typed "remember" instead of "resemble", my 
bad! I'm glad you agree with me though, I'm writing a paper comparing the 
two as we speak
comments.author: Zachary Duke

comments.text:
+Zachary Duke Good points! Its hard to believe that "Duel" was a made for 
tv movie, considering how epic it is.
comments.author: bluestate69

comments.text:
I find the scene where the truck and the car go over the cliff in Duel to 
visually remember the scene in Jaws where the shark is killed. Think of the 
massive plume of dirt in Duel, as the massive "plume" of blood in the water 
in Jaws. In Duel, you see the two vehicles peering through the dirt and 
dust on and off as they make their descent, and in Jaws, you can see the 
sharks fin through the heavy cloud of blood as it makes its descent. I have 
no point to this comment, I just thought that it was a very interesting 
similarity.
comments.author: Zachary Duke

comments.text:
+Ewan Trinity
that is cool. now i have to watch both endings again!
comments.author: bluestate69

comments.text:
Wanna know something cool? In DUEL the scene where the truck goes over the 
Cliff, the noise used for the truck falling is a dinosaur roar. In JAWS 
when Brody kills the shark and you see its body sink to the bottom of the 
ocean, that same roar is used. Steven Spielberg added the sound effect 
because he feels a kinship between JAWS and DUEL and since they're both 
"about these leviathans targeting everyman". He also said he added the roar 
to JAWS as a way of saying thank you to DUEL for giving him a career. All 
though, i don't know where the dinosaur roar comes from.
comments.author: Ewan Trinity

comments.text: +bluestate69  Yeah, "Duel" was super scary.
comments.author: sdsioux11

comments.text:
+Naturyl
Well,  Jaws was pretty damn good(the first one, not the monstrosities that 
came later, actually 2 wasn't that bad). Especially Robert Shaw's infamous 
parts!
I have often wondered if they did have the driver in the diner? It was 
obviously some stunt driver anyway, but it would be interesting movie 
trivia to find out!
You said it with the truck "itself" being the monster. it was dark, huge, 
its high powered exhaust system puttered and roared like a beast's 
respiratory system. I wonder if that truck still exists somewhere? Was 
there more than one? Was it destroyed in the last scene? Be cool to find it 
and BUY it! ha.
comments.author: bluestate69

comments.text:
+bluestate69 You ever try to figure out who the driver is? I've concluded 
it's impossible. I've looked at everything and can't positively identify 
anyone as the driver. Undoubtedly this is on purpose, as you suggest. The 
truck itself is the enemy - the monster. And to me it is Spielberg's best 
work, I think that afterward he fell into fame and money and went for the 
easier, more "sentimental" stories, as you suggest.
comments.author: Naturyl

comments.text:
+Naturyl
I think you nailed it there (with loneliness and alienation)! He was a 
traveling salesman, all alone, on the road. He's doing everything right, 
but a psycho picks him out of the crowd, and decides to make his life hell. 
He tries to tell others, but they all look at him as if he's the crazy one 
(hinting at an apathetic society?). The greatest thing he did (Speilberg), 
was making that diesel truck a character. We NEVER see the truck driver, 
just the truck! As if the driver is the physical embodiment of that truck. 
We might have seen him in the diner, but who was it? We were in the same 
position as Weaver's character in that sense. If I was to teach a film 
class, this is one film that would be mandatory viewing.
Watching "Duel" makes you wonder what  happened to Speilberg? It seemed 
like he got sentimental, in his storytelling, perhaps? Oh well, he's still 
a decent filmmaker.
You also nailed it with gritty. Every time I watch "Duel", I feel parched, 
like I need a beverage. Sorry for rambling man!
comments.author: bluestate69

comments.text:
+bluestate69 My snaaaakes!!! Muh snnnaaaaaaakes!!! yeah, I find that girls 
don't tend to care for it. Wife did not like it. I don't see how a person 
could NOT like it. She says "it was watchable." But to me it contains every 
element of the kind of implausible yet gritty real-world horror scenario 
and a great commentary on the loneliness and alienation of 70's 
middle-class life.
comments.author: Naturyl

comments.text:
+Naturyl
the paranoia scene, in the diner, is classic! and of course, you gotta love 
the snake lady. she showed up in a bunch of 70's films. i have not come 
across lots of girls who have liked it. i watched it with my brother, when 
i was 10. i was freaked out by semis for a while after that! i am convinced 
that the film might not have worked, had it not been Dennis Weaver. then 
again, the cinematography (and pacing, editing etc.) is so amazing, that it 
would  have to still be a great film without him.
comments.author: bluestate69

comments.text:
+bluestate69 I am a maniac about it. I force wife and girlfriend to watch 
it. I know everything about it. Gimme a ham sandwich on rye, R-Y-E?
comments.author: Naturyl

comments.text:
+Mary Moroschan They can survive in fresh water. There was a documentary 
that came out surrounding the Great White and the Bull Shark. I'm not sure 
if it is on YT (probable), but some of the attacks near or up rivers that 
were attributed to Whites were probably Bull sharks.
comments.author: Dave Pipe

comments.text:
+Gavin Wolfe
Have a look at the Wiki entry & be afraid, be *very* afraid!
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bull_shark#Interactions_with_humans
comments.author: Dave Pipe

comments.text:

doesn't swim as well as they do? ;-)

OK, great... Now fears are going from the White shark to the Bull shark.

comments.text:

Bull sharks attack without provocation, so you just have to swim like

comments.author: Dave Pipe

comments.text:
Ohh, wow!! Uhhmmmm, doesn't the frantic swimming trigger the sharks hunt,

comments.author: Gavin Wolfe

comments.text:
+Gavin Wolfe
Had the fun of swimming like mad in the Philippines to get to a dugout 
canoe. A bull shark had somehow got inside the reef at Black Sands Beach. 
There were about 15 of us who would have impressed any Olympic swimming 
scout! It was shot dead by a couple of the canoe owners.

comments.author: MNDHFilms

comments.text:
+John Cornell  
Yeah, they've tagged and tracked them swimming from the west coast of Fl to 
Texas and down to Mexico. He reported the sighting but people didn't 
believe it was as big as he said.
comments.author: John Balfour

comments.text:
+John Balfour

Really? I didn't know any had been tracked to Texas. I know they have been 
tracked up and down and across the Atlantic but I haven't heard of any 
being tracked across the Gulf yet. I've only hear of them off the west 
coast of Florida so far. My friend who lives in Texas will be interested. 
Did he report it to anyone?
comments.author: John Cornell

comments.text:
+John Cornell It was like 5 miles off the Texas coast he said. Apparently 
they have been tracked swimming all across the Gulf.
comments.author: John Balfour

comments.text:
+John Balfour
Where in the Gulf of Mexico? Do you know? They are supposed to be very rare 
there and I don't think they get much further in the Gulf than off Florida, 
but I could be wrong.
comments.author: John Cornell

comments.text:
+John Cornell They are in some documentaries, but very rarely do they show 
up unfortunately. A friend of mine told me his father had gone deep sea 
fishing in the Gulf of Mexico last year. He had hooked a marlin and almost 
had it worn out when a White that was almost as long as the 30ft boat came 
by and took it. So there are real monsters out there and maybe one day 
they'll get one on video.
comments.author: John Balfour

comments.text:
+John Balfour

There have been a few circa 20 footers 'accidentally' caught in nets around 
Taiwan over the years. Maybe that's one of the best places??? A film crew 
would be waiting for aeons to get footage though.
comments.author: John Cornell

comments.text:
Yes, they usually go to areas where young sharks predominate. It would be 
fascinating if a 25 foot White showed up while they were filming in a cage 
though.
comments.author: John Balfour

comments.text:
True. However most shark documentaries go to areas where the juvenile and 
sub adult great white sharks prey on small pinnipeds. The very very large 
great white sharks don't seem to be around those places, although off 
California at the Farallon Islands and some other places nearby where they 
have massive elephant seals, great white sharks of 18ft and over are 
regularly seen. Water clarity is poor there though so they don't do much 
underwater filming.
comments.author: John Cornell

comments.author: mysanuty

comments.text:
Thank god the shark kept breaking down during filming.  That's the only 
reason we don't see it in it's entirety until this far into the film. 
 Spielberg originally wanted to show the shark a lot more during the film 
but because it kept breaking down, he decided to go with a Hitchcockian 
approach.  By not showing the shark until this point made this scene all 
the more brilliant.  That's great filmmaking! ﻿
comments.author: bigleaguechew87

comments.text:
Not quite true. The early scenes were filmed before the shark was even 
scheduled to be used. Spielberg wanted to show the shark more during the 
sea hunt but that's when the shark started breaking down.....during the 
second half of the film set on the boat. The first half of Jaws went 
according to plan. The suspense and the unseen shark was deliberate.
comments.author: John Cornell

comments.text:
That was supposed to be Samuel L. Jackson's head coming out of the water,

The reason why that's such a great line is because that line was not in the

driving in the movie as well.﻿

comments.text:
+TechGhost Believe me, I hate Jaws 4. The only reason I ever liked it was 
because I was like, 8 (I'm 10 now) and I didn't know anything about why 
people hated it. But, looking back (I haven't watched the 4th one in a 
while), I say in my head, "really? A giant shark jumping out of the water 
and roaring like a dinosaur?"
comments.author: Garet McKenna

comments.text:

other people don't
like jaws 4 but if you like it. so it doesn't matter if you like jaws 4 and 
hate jaws 3. its just your opinion :)
comments.author: TechGhost

comments.text:
+TechGhost When I first saw all the movies, in my opinion, I thought Jaws 4 
was the best, Jaws 3 was the worst, Jaws 1 was in 2nd place, and Jaws 2 was 
in 3rd place.
But know, when I look back at it, and saw why people *didn't* like Jaws 4, 
I changed my opinion and said the first was the best, 2nd came in 2nd, 3rd 
came in 3rd, and 4th came in last.
